ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learnt so much about Buddhism, the philosophy, the traditions, its development in China, and lots of Sanskrit terms.
I learned about basic themes in Buddhism, especially Chinese Buddhism. I also improved my ability in reading and translating Classical Chinese.
I learned how to translate complex Classical Chinese texts into English and define key Buddhist terminology.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: it's great. I wish the assignment instructions could be more clear

The course is a great introduction to Chinese Buddhism for students who can read Classical Chinese. I enjoy the format of the course as a seminar with a mixture of student translation and comments from the professor. There is no major weakness.
The course provided a basic introduction to Chinese Buddhist texts. It was a very interesting seminar.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: yes, for people interested in Buddhism but lack the incentive to do self-study. If not b/c of this course, I would never read these much buddhist texts and sutras.
I would recommend this course to students who have good preparation in Classical Chinese and are interested in Chinese thought in general.
If the student has the required background in Chinese then I would highly recommend this seminar.

extras.title: EALL 221 01/EALL 521 01/RLST 486 01/RLST 568 01 - Intro to Chinese Buddhist Lit
